Q4: Good pace and level of detail for the audience.  It would have been nice to see you step out from behind the podium to "engage" with your audience; and speaking with more confidence would probably enable you to project your voice better.
Q6: Slides and handout were effective, not cluttered. I liked the comparison chart in the handout. That is the kind of information that will lead people to file the handout for future reference.  Using a pointer would have helped you draw  attention to specific data on charts/graphs you wanted to highlight.
Q8: Very good presentation of material.  Background was effective and not too long.  Objectives were measurable and aligned with the seminar. You did a very good job of setting up the controversy.
Q10: Good presentation of study methods and results. For the first study, absolute pregnancy rates would have been helpful to better understand the risk of pregnancy in the study population before considering OR with overweight/obesity.
Q12: Excellent discussion of the role of pharmacists; comprehensive and patient focused.
Q14: When soliciting questions, pause and allow some time for people to formulate their question.
Q16: You did a good job answering questions and considering how you would apply this knowledge to clinical practice.  You really seem to know the content, and were good at stating where/how this data can support clinical decision-making.
Q19: You gave a very good presentation - content was very solid.  My main suggestion is to work on presenting with more confidence; in almost all cases you will know the content better than anyone else in the room. (And remember to try to "have fun" and enjoy the opportunity you've been given to share this knowledge.)

Q4: Speaking pace was good, but the presentation ran a bit long.  Eye contact could have been better, may have been due to looking at notes.  Watch for swinging arm/hand with pointer.
Q6: Several slides with tables could not be read from the back of the room.  Remember to orient audience to tables and figures.
Q8: Decent background and objectives were measurable and related to the presentation. Unsure of your interest in the topic. The meta-analysis information would have been helpful to have as part of the background vs. conclusion. Prevalence of NEC plus cost/burden of illness information would help to establish the "problem" from a societal perspective.
Q10: Objective and methods accurately presented. Rationale for treatment window would have been useful.  Results were presented, but several tables could not be read from the back of the room.  In study 2, slide was titled null hypothesis, but the actual hypothesis was presented.
Q12: Conclusions were probably more strongly supported by data from meta-analysis briefly reviewed vs. the studies presented.
Q14: Did a good job answering questions.  Be sure to give enough time for people to formulate questions before moving on when asking for questions mid-presentation.
Q19: Overall a solid presentation.  Work on eye contact and readability of key information in slides. A main critique is on the flow.   While the study data was presented well, presenting the meta-analysis data at the end seemed to do more to support conclusions than the data presented.  Suggest using meta-analysis to demonstrate what is known and what gaps remain, and then use the data from the studies to help fill the gap and move closer to resolving the controversy.
